name: Auchindoun Castle, near Dufftown
terrain: Track, path, field.

name: Plockton Crags and the two lochs
terrain: Good tracks throughout.

name: Loch Achaidh na h-Inich from Balmacara
terrain: Well-marked path gives mostly good going, some slightly wetter sections.

name: Balmacara Woods and Reraig circuit
terrain: Waymarked paths throughout; a fair amount of ascent is involved and there is one very steep descent - which can be avoided by taking the short cut.

name: Portchullin circuit from Achmore
terrain: Path with very boggy section, track and minor road.

name: Duncraig Castle from Plockton
terrain: Clear but rugged paths, fair amount of up and down.

name: Balmacara to Kyle of Lochalsh
terrain: There is a clear path throughout, some rougher sections and can be boggy at times.

name: Plockton Explorer
terrain: Streets, paths and tracks; climb to viewpoint is on rough and rocky path.

name: Papa Westray - the island circuit
terrain: Mostly grassy coastal path, faint in places but all fences have stiles. Some rougher sections.

name: East Coast walk, South Ronaldsay
terrain: Grassy clifftop path; can be overgrown in places. Some sections of tarred lane.

name: Castle O'Burrian and Bay of Tafts - Westray
terrain: Cliff top paths, tracks, beach and minor road.

name: Noup Head, Westray
terrain: Mostly grassy clifftops; track for return.

name: Pierowall - Kirk, Castle and Beach, Westray
terrain: Tarmac roads, grassy tracks, rough ground near beach.

name: Westray west coast walk
terrain: Coastal walking, faint path, stiles

name: Tuquoy and Mae Sand, Westray
terrain: Grassy coast path, faint at times - can be very overgrown in parts in summer; return along tarmac road.

name: Cuilags, St John's Head and the Old Man of Hoy
terrain: Minor roads, steep ascent, pathless moorland very boggy in places; unprotected cliff edge. Navigation skills needed.

name: Sannox to Lochranza: Cock of Arran
terrain: After Laggan Cottage the route becomes rocky and wet underfoot in places, easy rocky scrambling over boulders at An Scriodan.

name: Glen Rosa and the Blue Pool
terrain: Varied; woodland paths, well-made glen paths, tracks, minor road. The route can be boggy in places.

name: Glen Cloy and the Fairy Glen, Brodick
terrain: Clear paths, forestry tracks and surfaced roads.

name: Clauchland Hills and Corriegills, Brodick
terrain: Tarmac roads, grassy fields, paths and clear tracks, boggy in places.

name: North Sannox viewpoint walk
terrain: Woodland / hill path, a little boggy in places. Becoming crowded by new conifers higher up.

name: Goatfell, from Brodick Castle
terrain: Good footpaths for most of the route; the final section weaves steeply up through granite boulders to the summit.

name: Fisherman's walk circuit, Brodick
terrain: Tracks, good woodland paths, sandy beach, tarmac lanes and pavements.

name: Chatelherault Country Park, near Hamilton
terrain: Well maintained beaten earth and aggregate paths, though steep and potentially muddy in places. Several flights of steps.

name: Isle of Muck coastal circuit
terrain: Mostly pathless going, some sheep tracks, short stretches of boggy ground etc.

name: Beinn Airein via Gallanach
terrain: Minor road, path, then pathless moorland and fields, navigation skills and map needed.

name: Caisteal an Duin Bhain
terrain: Pathless going along ridge above sea.

name: The Cobbler, Arrochar
terrain: Clear paths with some steep rocky sections, particularly on the descent.

name: Gallanach and Aird nan Uan
terrain: Minor road / track with very little traffic to Gallanach. Final section on rougher path.

name: Beinn an Lochain
terrain: Boggy at first then a very steep ascent of a fine rocky ridge, but the scrambling is only mild.

name: Ben Donich, via Rest and Be Thankful
terrain: There is a fairly good path for most of the ascent, though it is not continuous on the summit plateau. There is some rocky ground with a short easy scramble at one point. Deep cleft-like cavities beside the path could become a trap when covered in snow.

name: Alltbeithe to Morvich
terrain: Remote and rugged but with good hill paths, wet in places.

name: Cannich to Glen Affric
terrain: Minor road, waymarked forestry tracks and paths.

name: Drumnadrochit to Cannich
terrain: Waymarked paths and forest tracks. Farm livestock near Shenval, dogs to be kept under tight control.

name: Beinn a' Choin, near Inversnaid
terrain: Very boggy, rough and largely pathless going on the hill.

name: Ben Venue from Ledard Farm
terrain: Path up the Ledard Glen is very muddy in places with a section of broken boardwalk requiring care. Boggy in the uppper glen. On Ben Venue itself the going is rough and rocky.

name: Ben Venue from Loch Achray
terrain: Good forest tracks and path to the col and a final rocky path to the summits

name: The Mell circuit, Glen Finglas
terrain: Waymarked paths, tracks and minor road.

name: Ledard Farm to Loch Achray
terrain: Path up the Ledard Glen is very muddy in places with a section of broken boardwalk requiring care. Boggy in the uppper glen. The going is then rocky and rough until good forest paths are reached which link to Loch Achray. It should be regarded as a hillwalk and full mountain clothing and equipment should be carried.

name: Castle Coeffin and Tirefour Broch from Point
terrain: Rough walking with some very boggy stretches and no clear path.

name: Tirefour Broch and Castle Coeffin from Achnacroish
terrain: First section of path can be boggy and the next to the broch is indistinct. Afterward the walk follows minor roads and tracks.

name: Great Trossachs Path: Inversnaid to Trossachs pier
terrain: Waymarked paths, shared mountain bike paths, and minor road. Steep, rough path for first section (can be avoided on road).

name: Ben Ledi
terrain: Well maintained hill path for the ascent, but rougher with some boggy sections on the descent. As with any mountain walk, hillwalking gear must be carried.

name: Primrose Hill, Loch Katrine
terrain: Waymarked; tarred lane and good forest path, steep ascent at times.

name: Loch Venachar circuit, near Brig o'Turk
terrain: Minor roads, shared cycle paths.

name: Achadun Castle, from Achnacroish
terrain: Mostly minor roads, then track and final path.

name: Port Ramsay Circuit (Lismore)
terrain: Faint coastal path then minor road

name: Achnacroish and Salen circuit (Lismore)
terrain: First section of path can be boggy but the rest of the walk follows tracks and minor roads. A short section of track at Salen can be impassable at very high tides.

name: Meall Glas and Sgiath Chuil from Glen Dochart
terrain: Extremely steep slopes between the two Munros; pathless terrain lower down and boggy paths.

name: The Brack and Cnoc Còinnich , Ardgartan
terrain: Rugged going: steep hill path for the ascent of the Brack; some pathless ground on the descent. Cnoc Còinnich  is mostly pathless but straightforward.

name: An Caisteal and Beinn a'Chròin, near Crianlarich
terrain: Short section of track and then path for most of the route, indistinct in places. Minor scramble on Beinn a'Chròin, avoidable via an awkward detour.

name: Beinn Narnain and Beinn Ìme
terrain: Rocky, steep and eroded path on Beinn Narnain with very mild scrambling. Beinn Ìme is a broad dome on this side and the return route has a good path.

name: Ben Vorlich via Loch Sloy
terrain: Good tracks for the approach then very steep climb on hill path; broad rocky ridge above.

name: Meall an Fhudair, near Inverarnan
terrain: Track at first, then a boggy ascent up fairly featureless rough terrain.

name: Beinn nan Imirean, from Auchessan
terrain: Boggy hill path for much of the ascent; final section is pathless.

name: Ben More and Stob Binnein
terrain: Very steep ascent and descent for almost all the walk. There are pathless sections with boggy ground, and some dangerous terrain if the route is lost. Higher up the ridges are broad with one avoidable scramble on Ben More.

name: Beinn Chabhair, from Inverarnan
terrain: Hill path; stony and eroded lower down, boggy across moors. Good path up the ridge itself.

name: Ben Vane, from Inveruglas
terrain: Track for the approach, then path up steep, rocky hillside.

name: Stob Coire Creagach (Binnein an Fhidhleir)
terrain: Wet ground at first then drier slopes of grass and rock. The ascent is extremely steep and pathless higher up.

name: Doune Hill and Beinn Eich, from Luss
terrain: Minor road, then grassy ridges; descent rougher and pathless. Lower slopes very boggy in places.

name: Ben Lomond
terrain: Clear path with some rocky sections, most especially on the alternative, rougher return route. As with all mountain walks, full hillwalking clothing and equipment must be carried. If there is snow on the route this includes an ice-axe and crampons.

name: Beinn Dubh - Glen Striddle horseshoe, Luss
terrain: Grassy hillwalking; some areas of peat on the plateau and some wetter sections of path lower down.

name: Aspen Path, Cashel Forest
terrain: Well-made paths through natural woodland with a fair amount of ascent, steep in parts. An easy walk for grade 2.

name: Tom na h-Airidh, Helensburgh
terrain: Woodland and moorland paths; the route is very muddy and can be hard to follow on the forest section.

name: Conic Hill, Balmaha
terrain: Good path on the ascent, with steps. The detour from the West Highland Way up to the summit involves a short rocky scramble.

name: Stank Glen
terrain: Forest paths and tracks; steep stone steps in places.

name: Lendrick Hill, near Brig o' Turk.
terrain: Good waymarked paths and tracks.

name: Lime Craig circuit, near Aberfoyle
terrain: Waymarked forest tracks and paths, very steep in places.

name: Little Druim Wood and the Brig o' Turk loop
terrain: Waymarked paths; can be very muddy in places.

name: Craigmore, near Aberfoyle
terrain: Waymarked forest tracks and paths to bench, then rougher, boggier unsigned path to summit.

name: Callander Crags
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks, some steep sections, can be slippery when wet.

name: Ben A'an
terrain: The excellent path has recently been rebuilt but the route is still steep.

name: Loch Katrine
terrain: Minor road closed to most vehicles, some short steep sections.

name: Great Trossachs Path 2: Trossachs Pier to Callander
terrain: Waymarked tracks, shared mountain bike paths, and minor roads.

name: Beinn Luibhean
terrain: Path initially, then steep, pathless, mostly grassy slopes.

name: Leannach Forest circuit
terrain: Good forest tracks and paths, gentle climbs.

name: Glen Loin and Coiregrograin, Arrochar
terrain: Good path or track throughout; long with some ascents

name: Kinlochard and the Crannog
terrain: Well graded forestry tracks throughout. The route is not waymarked.

name: Succoth Circuit, Arrochar
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks; a steady zig-zag ascent to begin with.

name: Ardgartan shore and woodlands
terrain: Paths, tracks and minor road.

name: Tarbet Isle Walk, near Tarbet
terrain: Good paths, gentle up and down sections.

name: Cruach Àrdrain and Beinn Tulaichean
terrain: Pathless and boggy ascent and descent from the ridge, the descent is also rough going. The ridge linking the two Munros has a path and is more straightforward.

name: Arrochar - Tarbet link path
terrain: Well surfaced, waymarked, route with some up and down and steep first section.

name: Creag Mac Ranaich and Meall an t-Seallaidh
terrain: Good track as far as the bealach between then peaks, then rougher, pathless and steep going.

name: Mountain lookout trail, Crianlarich
terrain: Well-made paths and tracks; some steps.

name: Falls of Falloch
terrain: Well-made path, children need supervision near waterfall and river edge.

name: Stob a' Choin, from Inverlochlarig
terrain: Pathless, very steep, rough and boggy terrain.

name: Balquhidder to Brig O'Turk via Glen Finglas
terrain: Moorland path, very boggy in places, and tracks and minor road. Route climbs to 408 metres at an exposed pass.

name: Beinn Stacath, from Glen Buckie
terrain: Pathless and boggy terrain; river crossing can be avoided by 1km detour

name: Benvane, from Glen Buckie
terrain: Straightforward hillwalking on open ground, some boggy areas. Livestock so dogs to be under tight control.

name: Beinn an t-Sìdhean, Strathyre
terrain: Steep paths up through the forest, very muddy in places, a short moorland section requiring navigation.

name: Kirkton Glen, Balquhidder
terrain: Forestry tracks for most of the walk with some easy paths; fair amount of ascent

name: Beinn Each from Loch Lubnaig
terrain: Hill path to Beinn Each - steep in places.

name: Glen Ogle Trail, Lochearnhead
terrain: Excellent path on cycle track, one steep section climbing up to it, but the return route has been badly neglected; it is very boggy, overgrown in places and requires careful navigation.

name: Creag an Tuirc, Balquhidder
terrain: Good tracks and paths; some ascent.

name: Strathyre circuit
terrain: Paths and forest tracks, short climbs.

name: Sallochy Forest Trail, Sallochy
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks; slightly muddy in places

name: Sallochy to Rowardennan
terrain: Waymarked clear path with up and down sections, some steep

name: Balloch Castle Country Park
terrain: Tarmac track and paths, mainly flat.

name: Helensburgh and Rhu explorer, Helensburgh
terrain: Woodland paths, roads (some with no pavement).

name: Ardmore Point, near Helensburgh
terrain: Good path

name: Ardess History Trail
terrain: Waymarked trail on woodland paths with some up and down sections.

name: Luss Heritage Trail
terrain: Very good paths with some steps but mainly level.

name: Inchcailloch island
terrain: Good woodland paths with some steps and ascent.

name: Balmaha Millennium Forest path
terrain: Waymarked path with one steep ascent and a narrow section on the edge of Loch Lomond

name: Bochastle and the Falls of Leny
terrain: Forest tracks, steep path and cycle track - a strenuous walk for Grade 1. The detour to the Falls of Leny is rough and care is needed near the falls.

name: Loch Lomond Shores walk, Balloch
terrain: Well-made paths.

name: Loch Àrd and Ghleannain Loch, near Aberfoyle
terrain: Forest tracks and paths with some steep sections.

name: Doon Hill and Fairy Knowe, Aberfoyle
terrain: Waymarked tracks and paths, some fairly steep ascents.

name: Bracklinn Falls, Callander
terrain: Good path and track with some steps - walk to the Falls is suitable for some baby buggies. Care should be taken at the Falls where there are steep drops and slippery stones. Return along minor road.

name: Achray Water circular
terrain: Forest paths (partial waymarkers) with some up and down.

name: Lochan Spling, Aberfoyle
terrain: Easy forest tracks throughout; almost level.

name: Loch Drunkie
terrain: Good waymarked paths and tracks; short steep climb on first loop.

name: Inversnaid RSPB nature trail
terrain: Narrow but mostly clear woodland paths, many steps.

name: Culter Fell circular, near Biggar
terrain: Steep hill path to Culter Fell; continuation becomes boggier but eased by a windfarm track towards Hudderstone before final good grass track for the descent.

name: Tinto from Wiston Lodge
terrain: The approach is across often wet and muddy fields. Higher up on the steeper slopes the path has fallen into disuse and is not clear throughout.

name: Flanders Moss National Nature Reserve, near Kippen
terrain: Boardwalk path, viewing tower to climb

name: The Complete Falls of Clyde circuit
terrain: Good paths throughout, lots of ascent and descent.

name: Tinto from the north
terrain: Straightforward and very wide, clear path.

name: Loch Venachar forestry walk
terrain: Forest tracks and private tarmac roads throughout

name: Duncryne hill, by Gartocharn
terrain: Clear path, steep in parts.

name: Callander to Falls of Leny circuit
terrain: Level cycle track and rougher woodland path

name: King's Seat Hill from Tillicoultry to Dollar
terrain: Hill path, some indistinct and boggy sections.

name: Ben Cleuch circular
terrain: Hill path throughout. The upper slopes are grassy but parts of the descent and the Mill Glen sections have steep slopes. Slight scramble out of the Mill Glen.

name: Dumyat from Blairlogie
terrain: Rough and steep hill path, some indistinct sections where navigation skills essential. Short boggy areas.

name: Around Ben Shee, Glen Devon
terrain: Waymarked paths, but rough going on the hill and often wet in places.

name: Glen Sherup horseshoe, Glen Devon
terrain: Forestry roads and grassy upland paths, wet in places.

name: West Lomond via the Bunnet Stane
terrain: Hill paths throughout, faint in places on the descent.

name: Saline Hill and Easter Cairn, Saline
terrain: Mixed; short sections of minor road, track, various paths - some of them very overgrown at times. Very boggy in some fields. Pathless sections on the hill.

name: Bishop Hill circular from Holl Reservoir
terrain: Tracks and hill-paths; some sections can be very boggy.

name: East Lomond from Glenrothes
terrain: Good paths for the ascent with generally mild gradients. The descent route suggested is initially steep and has some rough, pathless sections - return by the route of ascent if unsure.

name: Palacerigg Country Park, Cumbernauld
terrain: Good paths and tracks.

name: Douglas Estate lochs and Castle Dangerous, Douglas
terrain: Tarmac lanes, tracks and grassy paths; section around furthest loch can be a little overgrown.

name: The Binn and Kinghorn Loch, from Burntisland
terrain: Varied - waymarked paths on grass and in woods; also tracks, lanes and beach if the tidal alternative is taken.

name: Baron's Haugh and Dalzell Estate, near Motherwell
terrain: Clear paths throughout; one section is prone to be wet.

name: The Falls of Clyde classic, New Lanark
terrain: Clear path with many steps and lots of short up and down sections. Care should be taken with children on boardwalk section next to river or above cliffs. Suggested return route is muddy but you could return via the outward route.

name: Spectacle E'e falls circular, Strathaven
terrain: Pavements, grassy paths (with stiles) and farm tracks.

name: Strathclyde Loch, Motherwell
terrain: All good paths, suitable for pushchairs.

name: The Hidden Side of the Falls of Clyde, near Lanark
terrain: Mostly waymarked paths, sometimes close to unfenced gorge edge - care needed.

name: Cioch na h'Oighe to Goatfell
terrain: There is scrambling and some exposure on Cioch na h'Oighe; optional scrambling on North Goatfell.

name: Drumpellier Country Park, Coatbridge
terrain: Good paths and tracks.

name: Cìr Mhòr and Beinn Tarsuinn
terrain: Rough bouldery mountain paths, rocky in parts, some boggy sections. Starts and ends on a good track through Glen Rosa.

name: Calderglen, East Kilbride
terrain: Good woodland paths.

name: Sannox Horseshoe
terrain: Very challenging, with a good deal of scrambling and also loose rock on many sections. Careful navigation essential.

name: Caisteal Abhail, via North Glen Sannox
terrain: Good paths lower down; some pathless going up to ridge then good ridgewalking to summit tors

name: Beinn Tarsuinn via The 3 Beinns circuit, Glen Rosa
terrain: Rough bouldery paths, very boggy in Coire a' Bhradain until the high ground is reached. Starts and ends on a good track through Glen Rosa.

name: Holy Isle - Mullach Mòr ascent
terrain: Rough footpaths with some minor hands-on scrambling over rocks below the summit of Mullach Mòr. Easier path on return by shore.

name: Goatfell, from Corrie
terrain: Very rocky mountain footpaths, crossing some very steep terrain with scrambling in places. Any more difficult scrambling can be avoided.

name: Fife Coastal Path 5: Lower Largo to St Monans
terrain: Clear path, sometimes muddy, sandy beach or rougher dune path as high tide alternative

name: Fife Coastal Path 9: Kingsbarns to St Andrews
terrain: Clear path, sometimes muddy, many short steep sections, straightforward rock step on coast.

name: Hill of Tarvit and Scotstarvit from Ceres
terrain: Tracks, minor roads and paths. Short optional ascent to the summit is steep and pathless up grass.

name: Fife Coastal Path 8: Crail to Kingsbarns
terrain: Signed coastal path. The route is rough going at times, on rocky shore or alongside.

name: Tay Bridge & Balmerino, from Wormit
terrain: Clear paths and tracks; some sections can be very muddy. Care needed on one section above drop to the shore.

name: Norman's Law, from Luthrie
terrain: Mostly tracks, rougher hill-path near summit. Return route has one boggy section.

name: Craighall Den circular, Ceres
terrain: Waymarked paths, one section becomes overgrown in summer, old lanes, and riverside paths.

name: The Rock and Spindle, from St Andrews
terrain: Clear path, sometimes muddy, lots of steps.

name: Devilla Forest - Four Lochs, near Kincardine
terrain: Woodland paths and forest tracks. Rougher section to Keir Dam.

name: Castlehill Trails, Glen Devon
terrain: Clear waymarked paths and tracks, boggy in places.

name: Clackmannan and the Towers
terrain: Route indistinct on descent from Clackmannan Tower and can be muddy; livestock often present. Careful navigation needed.

name: Dumyat by the hill path
terrain: Good hill path.

name: North Third Reservoir, near Stirling
terrain: Paths throughout, can be muddy and rough. Steep up and down from the crags.

name: Airthrey Loch & Hermitage Woods, Stirling University
terrain: Cyclepath around the loch och at University, but also rough woodland path with steep sections.

name: Castle Campbell and Dollar Glen
terrain: Narrow path above steep gorge, railings in places, steps and steep sections.

name: Mill Glen, Tillicoultry
terrain: Clear and popular path; however there are many steps, it is rough in places especially where it has fallen into the river requiring a short rocky scramble requiring care and some agility - hence the route is given a grade of 2.

name: Alva Glen
terrain: Clear and popular path; the second section where it climbs across the flanks of the gorge has unprotected drops and steep ascent, so the walk is given grade 2.

name: Bannockburn, near Stirling
terrain: Riverside and field paths and pavements.

name: Rumbling Bridge Gorge and Crook of Devon
terrain: Woodland and field paths, short sections on pavement and road.

name: Blairadam Forest walks, near Kelty
terrain: Forestry roads and surfaced woodland paths.

name: Pirnmill Hills: Mullach Buidhe of Beinn Bharrain
terrain: Boggy approach path. Some tricky scrambling on the ridge, but this can be bypassed. Straightforward hillwalking on the tops, with a good path on the final descent.

name: Cambuskenneth Abbey  from Stirling
terrain: Pavement and riverside path - suitable for buggies, short underpass.

name: Laggan circuit, from Lochranza
terrain: Rough bouldery paths, some wet sections and easy rock scrambling on the Coastal Way at An Sgirodain.

name: Sail Chalmadale, from Dougarie
terrain: Good path then estate tracks initially, then very rough moorland. There are two shallow concrete fords to cross.

name: Loch na Davie circuit, Lochranza
terrain: Rough bouldery paths, very boggy in places. Starts and ends with a section of quiet road walking.

name: Lochan a' Mhill, Catacol
terrain: Faint and often boggy paths and pathless moorland.

name: Loch Tanna, from Catacol
terrain: Rough bouldery paths, very boggy in places. A short section of quiet road walking.

name: West Lomond from Craigmead
terrain: Clear paths, steep and eroded in places, farm track

name: St Ninians and Loch Fitty from Kingseat
terrain: Good tracks and paths to the St Ninians site. The bings or landscape mounds are ascended by paths which are very steep in places, but can also be climbed by longer spiralling paths or avoided entirely.

name: Benarty Hill from Vane Farm
terrain: Clear hill paths, steep in places, steps on descent.

name: Lindores Loch circuit, Grange of Lindores
terrain: Paths - rough in places, minor roads, short section of main road with no pavement. Crosses farmland - dogs should be kept under tight control.

name: Benarty Hill, near Ballingry
terrain: Good forest and moorland paths.

name: Craigluscar Hill, near Dunfermline
terrain: Grassy and woodland paths; faint at times.

name: Bishop Hill circular from Scotlandwell
terrain: Good path for the ascent, steep at times; route less obvious on the plateau. Descent route is very steep and requires careful navigation - return by ascent route if in doubt.

name: East Lomond circuit, Falkland
terrain: Good hillpaths; steep ascent

name: Dumglow, Cleish Hills
terrain: Mostly clear paths, forest track on return.

name: Loch Leven Heritage Trail, Kinross
terrain: Well made, level path uitable for all terrain wheelchairs and buggies

name: Morven and Maiden Pap
terrain: Steep hills rising above boggy moorland; much of the route is pathless.

name: Trotternish Ridge
terrain: A very long and challenging walk with much ascent and descent; surprisingly for a major ridge there is no path most of the way, though there is much firm grassy going. Most people split it into a 2 day hike with a camp or bivvy on the ridge itself.

name: Hartaval and Baca Ruadh
terrain: Mostly grassy ridge-walking but with steep grassy and rocky ascents/descents from the bealachs

name: Arkle
terrain: Good approach track, then pathless ascent up heather and stones. The ridge to the final summit is rocky, and exposed at one point with a little straightforward scrambling on sometimes slippery quartzite.

name: The Storr - ascent
terrain: Mostly on hillwalking paths, with a couple of steep rocky/scrambly sections; boggy moorland with pathless stretches to finish.

name: Foinaven circuit
terrain: Extremely rough hillwalking. Good track up Srath Dionard but otherwise pathless; very boggy ground lower down, steep with boulders higher up.

name: Càrn Ban via Alladale
terrain: Landrover tracks for approach, with stalkers path up and down hill. Pathless grassy walking on the summits. Some boggy ground.

name: Meallan Liath Coire Mhic Dhughaill
terrain: Grassy stalkers' track for initial ascent, then pathless ridges - heather at first, becoming rockier. Descent crosses peat bogs and includes burn crossing.

name: Meall Horn
terrain: Good tracks for the approach and return, otherwise pathless but decent hillwalking terrain with one section of peat hags on ascent.

name: Càrn Chuinneag, Strath Carron, Ardgay
terrain: Good approach track, then stalkers' paths on the open hill. Short pathless section to summit; alternative return route is much rougher over boulders.

name: North Glen Sannox pools and falls
terrain: Good paths initially; rough boggier ground further up the glen.

name: Sannox to North Sannox
terrain: Good footpaths and tracks. Large and easy stepping stones across Sannox Burn.

name: Fallen Rocks, North Sannox
terrain: Easygoing track and path.

name: Glen Sannox, from Sannox
terrain: Good track then rougher paths; a crossing of stepping stones to complete the loop is optional.

name: Brodick Castle and the Hamilton Trail
terrain: The walk follows a maze of woodland footpaths and tracks; muddy in places. There are purple waymarkers but these do not cover the whole route.

name: Brodick and Lamlash circuit, Brodick
terrain: Paths and tracks throughout. Section beyond Corriegills Point can be wet, and flooded briefly at high tide.

name: Clauchlands Point and Dun Fionn
terrain: Track at first; the climb to Dun Fionn is on path which is overgrown with bracken in summer. Fields with livestock.

name: Drumadoon Point, Blackwaterfoot
terrain: Sandy beach, grassy footpaths and golf course paths. A stretch along a boulder path beneath the Doon.

name: Eas Mòr, Loch Garbad and the Library in the Woods, Kildonan
terrain: Good footpaths throughout.

name: Glenashdale Falls & Giant's Graves, Whiting Bay
terrain: Woodland footpath and tracks; fair amount of ascent and descent.

name: Holy Isle - the coast walk
terrain: Good grassy footpaths throughout.

name: Kildonan Shore walk
terrain: Metalled road, then rough tracks and beach.

name: King's Cave circuit, near Blackwaterfoot
terrain: Good forest paths, then rockier, rougher section down by the shore.

name: Kildonan Castle
terrain: Track, path, rough and rocky shoreline. Overgrown sections.

name: Machrie Moor stone circles
terrain: Good farm tracks and grassy footpaths.

name: Torrylin cairn and beach, Kilmory
terrain: Woodland path, tracks, pebbly beach and tarmac road.

name: West Sands, St Andrews
terrain: Sandy beach, narrow and rough path through dunes, surfaced path between golf courses.

name: Largo Law, from Upper Largo
terrain: Rough path, some sections can be very muddy. The hill section is steep and can be very slippery, particularly in descent.

name: Mount Hill and the Hopetoun Monument, Cupar
terrain: Minor roads, then rough vehicle tracks to the summit.

name: Preaching Cave and Kilpatrick Dun, Kilpatrick
terrain: Grassy path with burn crossing to Preaching Cave; path to Dun is very boggy in places with rough path.

name: Kingscross Point, Whiting Bay
terrain: Easy paths with stiles, minor roads and track

name: Meallach's Grave, Dyemill Forest near Lamlash
terrain: Waymarked forest paths and tracks; a little rougher up to Meallach's Tomb.

name: 7: Kings House to Kinlochleven
terrain: Easy to follow path but stony and rought in places, steep climb from Glencoe, then undulating section of exposed moorland, followed by a long descent on stony tracks to Kinlochleven.

name: 2: Drymen to Rowardennan
terrain: Forest tracks and then a hillpath over Conic Hill, followed by undulating and occasionally rough going closer to Loch Lomond.

name: Helensburgh to Garelochhead
terrain: Good woodland and moorland path, then minor roads. The final descent to Garelochhead involves a path which crosses fencelines and is very boggy in patches, but is waymarked.

name: Wooler to Lindisfarne
terrain: Country lanes, paths, sometimes muddy. Causeway to Lindisfarne only open twice a day at low tide - check tide times before setting out.

name: Kirk Yetholm to Wooler
terrain: Paths, quiet roads, moorland can be boggy underfoot and exposed in bad weather.

name: 3: North Bute circuit
terrain: Minor road, forestry track, and open farmland and moorland with only faint paths, can be very wet underfoot.

name: 2: Kilchattan Bay to Port Bannatyne
terrain: Paths, farm tracks and minor roads - mostly easy going but some patches can be very muddy.

name: Kingsbarns and Cambo circuit, Kingsbarns
terrain: Coastal and woodland paths, with some steps. Some sections can be muddy.

name: The Isle of May
terrain: Marked grassy paths; care is needed near to unprotected cliff edges. Visitors are asked to keep to the paths to avoid crushing puffin burrows.

name: Dunblane to Ashfield riverside walk, Dunblane
terrain: Clear path, two railway bridges, path narrow and close to the river at times.

name: Stirling Castle and Gowanhill
terrain: Good paths and pavements; fair amount of ascent.

name: Culross - Heritage walk
terrain: Paths, cobbles and pavements; can be muddy en-route to West Kirk

name: Falkirk Wheel and Antonine Wall, near Falkirk
terrain: Good surfaced paths, roads with pavement, Antonine Wall and Roman Fort can be wet underfoot.

name: Falkirk Wheel two canals circuit, near Falkirk
terrain: Good surfaced paths, short tunnel (can be wet), towpath, roads with pavement.

name: The Kelpies and the Helix, Falkirk
terrain: Good paths throughout.

name: Callendar Park and House, Falkirk
terrain: Tracks through woodland park; can be a little muddy at times.

name: Coire Fhionn Lochan
terrain: Grass and aggregate footpaths with a few rocky sections.

name: Fairy Dell, Lochranza
terrain: Surfaced and unsurfaced road, grassy tracks and aggregate footpath; wet or rough going in places.

name: North Queensferry coastal circuit
terrain: Clear coastal path, roads with pavements.

name: Maspie Den, Falkland
terrain: Good woodland paths but some steep ascent and muddy patches.

name: The Hill of Beath, near Cowdenbeath
terrain: Unmarked; mostly grassy tracks and paths, one steep loose pull. Livestock may be present.

name: Dunnet Head
terrain: Narrow paths in the heather with steep ascents and some boggy sections. Much of the route is along unprotected vertical cliff edges and great care is needed.

name: Keiss Castle and Nybster Broch, Nybster
terrain: Easy path to broch and then rough coastal walking on narrow clifftop path. The route is waymarked as part of the John o'Groats Trail but there is one barbed wire fence to climb.

name: Thurso Bay and Castle, Thurso
terrain: Fairly rough but grassy coastal path. Minor roads on return.

name: Holborn Head, Scrabster
terrain: Grassy cliff top paths, farm track, and road with pavement. The sheer cliffs are unprotected, and at one brief point a fence forces the route uncomfortably near the edge.

name: Beinn Edra from Glen Uig
terrain: Farm tracks, one very boggy pathless section, short grass higher up

name: Loch Sligachan
terrain: Good path until the final section near Sligachan; the route is boggier here and there are two streams to cross which may be awkward in wet weather.

name: Fingal's Pinnacles, Flodigarry
terrain: An excellent path for the outward walk uphill; the return walk crosses some pathless moorland and steep grass slopes

name: Ben Tianavaig, Braes
terrain: Unmarked hill paths throughout; one short section can be wet but otherwise the going is excellent. Unprotected cliff edges for much of the walk.

name: Ben Klibreck
terrain: Rough hill path, boggy and indistinct on some sections, with a steeper final ascent.

name: Ben Loyal
terrain: Easy tracks to begin with but the lower part of the mountain is extremely boggy with burn crossings. The ascent is pathless, steep and wet underfoot. The ridge itself gives pleasant walking; minor scrambling on the tors.

name: Ben Hee, from West Merkland
terrain: Approach track; boggy path up by burn. Upper part of hill and descent route are both pathless.

name: Talmine and Achininver Beach circuit
terrain: Rough and pathless coastal section, then minor road and finally path and often wet track over the moors.

name: Brora to Golspie coastal walk, Brora
terrain: Decent path along the coastline, mostly on dunes and field edges.

name: Ben Bhraggie, Golspie
terrain: Waymarked footpaths and tracks.

name: Torrisdale Bay and Broch, Invernaver
terrain: Coastal path, steep climb to broch, moorland pathless section - navigation skills needed, beach and riverside.

name: Badvoon Forest circuit, near Ardgay
terrain: Forest and landrover tracks for much of the distance, short section of more heathery path can be boggy. The route is partly waymarked.

name: Ward Hill and the Dwarfie Stane, Hoy
terrain: Minor roads, moorland path,

name: Flotta island explorer
terrain: Good tracks, tarmac roads, rougher grassy coastal paths

name: Lyrawa Hill and Scad Head, Hoy
terrain: Moorland path, rough underfoot in places.

name: Lyness Wartime Trail and Wee Fea hill, Hoy
terrain: Minor roads and track

name: Dunnet Forest
terrain: Woodland paths waymarked but muddy in places. There is a shorter all abilities path here as well.

name: Cave of Gold, Kilmuir
terrain: The walk crosses rough croft pasture land; if you really must take a dog it should be kept on a short lead. The descent to see the cave is down an extremely steep grass slope which could be dangerous in the wet.

name: Flodigarry Fossils Walk, Flodigarry
terrain: Gentle paths down to the coast, but the walking along the shore itself is very awkward, crossing slippery boulders.

name: Forsinain Trail, Strath Halladale
terrain: Waymarked route through the bogs and forestry. Some sections have flagstones to pass the bogs but other parts of the route are extremely wet underfoot.

name: Poulouriscaig, from Armadale
terrain: Old track, boggy in places and indistinct for one section.

name: Dornoch links and Embo circular, Dornoch
terrain: Clear paths, tracks and minor roads with optional section along the beach.

name: Loch Fleet and Balblair Wood
terrain: Clear path, forestry track and pebbly shoreline.

name: Balblair Forest, near Bonar Bridge
terrain: Forest paths and tracks throughout.

name: Whaligoe Steps and the Cairn of Get
terrain: The path to the Cairn of Get is through rough pastures and is waymarked. The Whaligoe Steps are very steep with unprotected vertical drops into the sea; great care is needed.

name: St John's Point
terrain: Rough and boggy paths with high cliffs in places, paths easy to follow.

name: Badbea - Clearance Village
terrain: Well worn though rough path down to the Monument; optional continuation is on faint paths through the heather.

name: The Fairy Glen, near Uig
terrain: Mostly dry walking on good paths; reaching the top of Castle Ewen requires an awkward scramble step up.

name: Cata Sand and Tres Ness, Sanday
terrain: Grassy track and sandy beach. Final section more overgrown with some boggy patches.

name: North Ronaldsay circuit
terrain: Mostly shoreline walking; some sandy and grassy stretches but also awkward, slow going on tidal rocks and boulders at times.

name: Killin to Ardtalnaig
terrain: Minor road, moorland track, boggy pathless (but waymarked) section, steep climb on road.

name: Callander to Strathyre
terrain: Cycle paths and tracks throughout.

name: River Ayr Way 3: Stair to Ayr
terrain: Well-made aggregate footpaths and surfaced roads.

name: River Ayr Way 1: Glenbuck to Sorn
terrain: Well-made aggregate footpaths and surfaced roads including a section of the first tarmacadam road experiments.

name: Handa Island, near Tarbet
terrain: Good footpath, usually dry

name: Rosal and the Strathnaver Clearances
terrain: Forest track and path; the section around Rosal village is across grassy pastures where markers need to be followed closely.

name: Ferry Wood and the Ord, Lairg
terrain: Both loops are on waymarked paths; the Ferry Wood route is laid out to All Abilities standard and should be suitable for wheelchairs and pushchairs.

name: Cassley Falls and Rosehall Forest
terrain: Good clear, some uphill and downhill sections; steep flight of stone steps to descend near the river.

name: The Saddle, Forcan Ridge and Sgùrr na Sgìne
terrain: A tough mountain walk with steep and rugged terrain. Ascending via the Forcan Ridge is a hard and exposed scramble; this part of the walk can be avoided as indicated in the text (reducing the walk to Grade 4)

name: Aonach Buidhe, via Glen Elchaig
terrain: Excellent track up Glen Elchaig to near Iron Lodge - use of a mountain bike will save alot of time. Beyond the track the initial ascent is on very steep grass; the upper slopes are gentler but boggier.

name: South Glen Shiel Ridge: 7 Munros
terrain: Superb ridgewalking on a well defined grassy crest for much of the route. There are short sections of simple scrambling.

name: Sgùrr Gaorsaic, from Morvich
terrain: Good paths to the Bealach an Sgairne and beyond. The path becomes briefly boggy near Loch a' Bhealaich; the ascent to Sgùrr Gaorsaic itself is pathless hillside.

name: Càrn na Saobhaidhe, via Dunmaglass
terrain: Landrover track throughout - a mountain bike could be used. The track crosses a burn four times near the final section.

name: Corrieyairack Pass: Laggan to Fort Augustus
terrain: Minor road at first then good hill tracks through exposed terrain.

name: Craigmonie and the Divach Falls, Drumnadrochit
terrain: Waymarked forest footpaths, minor roads.

name: Càrn na h-Easgainn, near Moy
terrain: Landrover track throughout. Route is very exposed to the elements - hillwalking gear needed.

name: Aberfeldy to Pitlochry
terrain: Riverside and old railway paths, then hill path, boggy in places, finally forest tracks

name: Abriachan Trails
terrain: Good paths and tracks throughout, including a fair amount of ascent and descent.

name: Glen Strathfarrar Munros circuit
terrain: Fairly boggy approach. The hills give mostly excellent going with a couple of sections of more awkward boulders. A good stalkers path is used on the descent.

name: Càrn a' Choire Ghairbh and Aonach Shasuinn, Affric
terrain: Short extremely boggy section by Allt Garbh. Mostly pathless hillwalking, rough in places.

name: Bac an Eich, Strathconon
terrain: Good stalkers paths around the hill; higher slopes are pathless.

name: Sgùrr nan Ceathreamhnan group, Alltbeithe
terrain: There is a reasonable path along the ridges, boggy in parts on the ascent. The ridges themselves are mostly grassy, rocky in places. The short cut via Loch Coire nan Dearcag is steep and pathless.

name: Sands o' Wright, South Ronaldsay
terrain: Minor roads, grass/earth footpaths and good farm tracks.

name: Caisteal Bharraich, Tongue
terrain: Excellent path with some ascent; final few yards to the ruin are rougher.

name: Forsinard Flows and Tower, Forsinard
terrain: Excellent wooden walkway to the tower, then optional return along flagstone trails which can be slippery or wet in places.

name: Raven's Rock Gorge, near Rosehall
terrain: Good waymarked paths throughout.

name: Ceannabeinne Township Trail, near Durness
terrain: Waymarked route through croft pastures and high bracken in places.

name: Brothers Ridge - Sgùrr a Bhealaich Dheirg
terrain: Steep ascent to and from the ridge, but a clear path leads along the ridge.

name: Five Sisters of Kintail
terrain: The going is very steep on ascent; there is a little scrambling along the ridge itself and much rocky ground.

name: Sgùrr Mhic Bharraich
terrain: Excellent old hill-path as far as the bealach, but the mountain itself is otherwise pathless. A little boggy and rough in places.

name: Three lochs circuit, south Loch Ness
terrain: Straightforward walk through varied landscape on a mixture of path, track and minor road with some boggy sections.

name: Sgùrr a' Mhuilinn and Meallan nan Uan, Strathconon
terrain: Most of the route is pathless hillwalking. The lower ground is very wet but the hills above give good going, rockier in places.

name: Beinn a' Bha'ach Àrd
terrain: Minor road and track initially, then rough and boggy terrain with only occasional ATV track for ascent and no path for descent; ridge gives conditions underfoot.

name: 3: Strathblane to Croy
terrain: Surfaced shared cycle path to Kirkintilloch, then canal tow path, can be muddy in places.

name: 2: Balloch to Strathblane
terrain: Minor roads at first, then good paths throughout.
